section.name: SUPERSTITION & ERUDITION: Daily Life in the Middle Ages

comments:
This course concentrates on two very broad aspects of daily life in the Middle Ages (12th - 16th centuries). The first part, Erudition, focuses on the world in and around the University. The second part, Superstition, revolves around astrology, medicine and pharmacy. 

Students raved about this course. Students thought that the material was “captivating” and that the “readings supplemented the class very well.” Many students liked that each student was able to teach one lecture to the class. They thought that the course taught them skills that will carry them beyond Penn. 

Students generally found that Professor Brevart was engaging and stimulated student interest. Professor Brevart really got to know each of his students, providing many opportunities for students to speak with him during office hours. Many students thought that Professor Brevart was one of the best professors at Penn. 

The only assignments for this course were readings. There are two written exams and one presentation, and students found the workload to be manageable.
